A group is a monoid $G$ such that every element of $G$ admits an inverse. More explicitly, this means we are given a set $G$ with a law of composition $G \times G \longrightarrow G,(a, b) \longmapsto a b$, such that: (i) The law is associative, i.e., we have $(a b) c=a(b c)$ for $a, b, c \in G$. (ii) There exists $a$ unit element, i.e., an element $e \in$ such that $e a=a=a e$ for all $a \in G$. (iii) Every element $a \in G$ admits an inverse, i.e., an element $b \in G$ such that $a b=e=b a$. The group is called commutative or abelian if the law is commutative, i.e., if (iv) $a b=b a$ for all $a, b \in G$.
The order of an element $a$ in a group $G$ is defined as the order of the cyclic group generated by $a$ in $G$. It is the smallest positive integer $m$ such that $a^{m}=1$.
The zero ring is a ring where the unit element of addition (0) and the unit element of multiplication (1) are the same, i.e., 1=0. It consists of a single element 0.
An ideal $\mathfrak{a}$ in a ring $R$ is finitely generated if it admits a finite system of generators.

An integral domain $R$ satisfying the conditions that every element $a \in R-\left(R^{*} \cup\{0\}\right)$ can be uniquely written, up to associatedness and order, as a product of irreducible elements, and every element $a \in R-\left(R^{*} \cup\{0\}\right)$ is a product of prime elements. An element of a unique factorization domain is irreducible if and only if it is prime.

An element $p$ in a unique factorization domain $R$ is called a prime element if it generates a prime ideal, i.e., the ideal $(p)$ is such that if $p$ divides a product of elements in $R$, then $p$ divides at least one of those elements.

An A-module M is called a free A-module if it has a basis, i.e., a free system of generators. In this case, every element x in M admits a representation x = sum_{i in I} a_i x_i with coefficients a_i in A that are unique.

A field $K$ is called algebraically closed if every nonconstant polynomial $f$ of $K[X]$ admits a zero in $K$, or in other words, if $f$ decomposes in $K[X]$ into a product of linear factors. This means that $f$ admits a product decomposition $f=c \prod_{i}\left(X-\alpha_{i}\right)$ with a constant $c \in K^{*}$ as well as zeros $\alpha_{i} \in K$.

An extension field $\\[\mathbb{F}_q / \mathbb{F}_p\]$ is a field consisting of $q=p^n$ elements, where $p$ is a prime number and $n$ is a positive integer. This field is uniquely characterized up to isomorphism as a splitting field of the polynomial $X^q-X$ over $\\[\mathbb{F}_p\]$.

An ideal \(\mathfrak{a}\) in a ring \(R\) is called reduced if \(\mathfrak{a} = \operatorname{rad} \mathfrak{a}\), where \(\operatorname{rad} \mathfrak{a}\) is the set of all elements \(a \in R\) such that there exists some \(n \in \mathbb{N}\) with \(a^{n} \in \mathfrak{a}\).
A cycle involving $r$ elements is called an $r$-cycle and is denoted as $\pi = (x_{1}, \ldots, x_{r})$.

Implied_Association_Relationships.Explanation: The definition of the order of an element relies on the concept of a group, as it refers to the cyclic group generated by an element in a group.
A prime element is defined within the context of a unique factorization domain, which is a specific type of integral domain.
A reduced ideal is defined in terms of the radical of an ideal, which is a concept within ring theory.
An extension field is defined in terms of a base field, which is a fundamental concept in field theory.
